Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You know that little pink thing nestled 
in the corner of your eye? It’s actually the remnant 
of a third eyelid. Known as the “plica semilunaris,” it’s much more prominent in birds 
and a few mammals, and functions like a windshield wiper 
to keep dust and debris out of their eyes. But in humans, it doesn’t work. It’s vestigial, meaning it no longer 
serves its original purpose. There are several other vestigial 
structures like the plica semilunaris in the human body. Most of these became vestigial long 
before homo sapiens existed, quietly riding along from one of 
our ancestor species to the next. But why have they stuck 
around for so long? To answer this question, it helps to 
understand natural selection. Natural selection simply means that traits which help an organism survive and 
reproduce in a given environment are more likely to make it to the 
next generation. As the environment changes, traits 
that were once useful can become harmful. Those traits are often selected against, meaning they gradually disappear 
from the population. But if a trait isn’t actively harmful, 
it might not get selected against, and stick around even 
though it isn’t useful. Take the tailbone. Evolutionary biologists think that as the 
climate got drier and grasslands popped up, our tail-bearing ancestors left the trees 
and started walking on land. The tails that had helped them 
in the trees began to disrupt their ability 
to walk on land. So individuals with mutations that reduced
the length of their tails became more successful at life on land, surviving long enough to pass their short 
tails on to the next generation. The change was likely gradual over 
millions of years until, about 20 million years ago, our ancestors’ external tails disappeared 
altogether. Today, we know human embryos have tails
that dissolve as the embryo develops. But the stubby tailbone sticks around, probably because it doesn’t 
cause any harm— in fact, it serves a more minor function as the anchor point for certain 
other muscles. Up to 85% of people have a vestigial 
muscle called the “palmaris longus.” To see if you do, put your hand down on a flat surface 
and touch your pinkie to your thumb. If you see a little band pop up in the 
middle of your wrist, that’s the tendon that attaches to this 
now-defunct muscle. In this case, the fact that not everyone 
has it has helped us trace its function. Vestigial traits can persist when there’s 
no incentive to lose them— but since there’s also no incentive 
to keep them, random mutations will sometimes still
eliminate them from part of the population. Looking at our primate relatives, we can see that the palmaris longus 
is sometimes absent in those that spend more time on the land, but always present in those that spend 
more time in trees. So we think it used to help us swing 
from branch to branch, and became unnecessary when 
we moved down to land. The appendix, meanwhile, may once have 
been part of the intestinal system our ancestors used for digesting 
plant materials. As their diets changed, those parts of the
intestinal system began to shrink. Unlike other vestigial structures, though,
the appendix isn’t always harmless— it can become dangerously inflamed. For most of human history, a burst 
appendix could be a death sentence. So why did it stick around? It’s possible that it was very slowly on 
its way out, or that mutations simply hadn’t arisen 
to make it smaller. Or maybe it has other benefits— for example, it might still be a reservoir
of bacteria that helps us break down food. But the fact is, we’re not really sure why
the appendix persists. Evolution is an imperfect process. Human beings are the result of millions of
years of trial, error, and random chance— and we’re full of evolutionary relics 
to remind us of that.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the function of the “third eyelid” in birds?
Options: A. Wards off predators, B. Helps detect prey faster, C. Keeps dust and debris out of eyes, D. Attracts mates
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the vestigial structure located in the corner of the human eye? Options: A. Plica semilunaris, B. Palmaris longus, C. Tailbone, D. Appendix Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the primary reason why vestigial structures like the plica semilunaris have remained in the human body? Options: A. They provide a significant advantage for survival, B. They are actively selected for by natural selection, C. They do not cause harm and are not selected against, D. They are necessary for development Correct Option: C
Question 3: If a person has a palmaris longus muscle, what action can they perform to make the tendon visible? Options: A. Touching their thumb to their index finger, B. Touching their pinkie to their thumb, C. Flexing their wrist, D. Extending their arm Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the likely reason why the palmaris longus muscle is sometimes absent in primates that spend more time on land? Options: A. It is not necessary for swinging from branches, B. It is not necessary for walking on land, C. It is more prone to injury on land, D. It is less efficient for grasping Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the proposed original function of the appendix? Options: A. To aid in the digestion of plant materials, B. To filter waste from the bloodstream, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To produce hormones Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why might the appendix still be present in the human body despite being vestigial? Options: A. It has a significant benefit for survival, B. It has not had time to evolve out of the population, C. It may have other benefits, such as serving as a reservoir of bacteria, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: A person is diagnosed with a burst appendix. What is the most likely outcome if left untreated? Options: A. The appendix will heal on its own, B. The person will experience mild discomfort, C. The person will experience severe pain and potentially life-threatening complications, D. The person will not be affected Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the term for the process by which traits that are no longer useful are gradually eliminated from a population? Options: A. Natural selection, B. Genetic drift, C. Mutation, D. Selection against Correct Option: D
Question 9: How do evolutionary biologists think the tailbone became vestigial in humans? Options: A. As humans evolved to live in trees, the tailbone became less necessary, B. As humans evolved to walk on land, the tailbone became less necessary, C. As humans evolved to swim, the tailbone became less necessary, D. As humans evolved to fly, the tailbone became less necessary Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea that the existence of vestigial structures in humans illustrates? Options: A. Evolution is a perfect process, B. Humans are the pinnacle of evolution, C. Evolution is an imperfect process that results in remnants of past traits, D. Humans are not subject to the forces of evolution Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided set. However, based on the content and intent, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match, but it does not match the ground truth MCQ's intent. 

However, if I had to choose the closest match based on the content related to the "third eyelid," I would say that Question 1 is the closest match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You know that little pink thing nestled 
in the corner of your eye? It’s actually the remnant 
of a third eyelid. Known as the “plica semilunaris,” it’s much more prominent in birds 
and a few mammals, and functions like a windshield wiper 
to keep dust and debris out of their eyes. But in humans, it doesn’t work. It’s vestigial, meaning it no longer 
serves its original purpose. There are several other vestigial 
structures like the plica semilunaris in the human body. Most of these became vestigial long 
before homo sapiens existed, quietly riding along from one of 
our ancestor species to the next. But why have they stuck 
around for so long? To answer this question, it helps to 
understand natural selection. Natural selection simply means that traits which help an organism survive and 
reproduce in a given environment are more likely to make it to the 
next generation. As the environment changes, traits 
that were once useful can become harmful. Those traits are often selected against, meaning they gradually disappear 
from the population. But if a trait isn’t actively harmful, 
it might not get selected against, and stick around even 
though it isn’t useful. Take the tailbone. Evolutionary biologists think that as the 
climate got drier and grasslands popped up, our tail-bearing ancestors left the trees 
and started walking on land. The tails that had helped them 
in the trees began to disrupt their ability 
to walk on land. So individuals with mutations that reduced
the length of their tails became more successful at life on land, surviving long enough to pass their short 
tails on to the next generation. The change was likely gradual over 
millions of years until, about 20 million years ago, our ancestors’ external tails disappeared 
altogether. Today, we know human embryos have tails
that dissolve as the embryo develops. But the stubby tailbone sticks around, probably because it doesn’t 
cause any harm— in fact, it serves a more minor function as the anchor point for certain 
other muscles. Up to 85% of people have a vestigial 
muscle called the “palmaris longus.” To see if you do, put your hand down on a flat surface 
and touch your pinkie to your thumb. If you see a little band pop up in the 
middle of your wrist, that’s the tendon that attaches to this 
now-defunct muscle. In this case, the fact that not everyone 
has it has helped us trace its function. Vestigial traits can persist when there’s 
no incentive to lose them— but since there’s also no incentive 
to keep them, random mutations will sometimes still
eliminate them from part of the population. Looking at our primate relatives, we can see that the palmaris longus 
is sometimes absent in those that spend more time on the land, but always present in those that spend 
more time in trees. So we think it used to help us swing 
from branch to branch, and became unnecessary when 
we moved down to land. The appendix, meanwhile, may once have 
been part of the intestinal system our ancestors used for digesting 
plant materials. As their diets changed, those parts of the
intestinal system began to shrink. Unlike other vestigial structures, though,
the appendix isn’t always harmless— it can become dangerously inflamed. For most of human history, a burst

its way out, or that mutations simply hadn’t arisen 
to make it smaller. Or maybe it has other benefits— for example, it might still be a reservoir
of bacteria that helps us break down food. But the fact is, we’re not really sure why
the appendix persists. Evolution is an imperfect process. Human beings are the result of millions of
years of trial, error, and random chance— and we’re full of evolutionary relics 
to remind us of that.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To the best of our knowledge, up to ___% of people have a vestigial muscle called the “palmaris longus”.
Options: A. 15, B. 50, C. 85, D. 40
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
You know that little pink thing nestled 
in the corner of your eye? It’s actually the remnant 
of a third eyelid. Known as the “plica semilunaris,” it’s much more prominent in birds 
and a few mammals, and functions like a windshield wiper 
to keep dust and debris out of their eyes. But in humans, it doesn’t work. It’s vestigial, meaning it no longer 
serves its original purpose. There are several other vestigial 
structures like the plica semilunaris in the human body. Most of these became vestigial long 
before homo sapiens existed, quietly riding along from one of 
our ancestor species to the next. But why have they stuck 
around for so long? To answer this question, it helps to 
understand natural selection. Natural selection simply means that traits which help an organism survive and 
reproduce in a given environment are more likely to make it to the 
next generation. As the environment changes, traits 
that were once useful can become harmful. Those traits are often selected against, meaning they gradually disappear 
from the population. But if a trait isn’t actively harmful, 
it might not get selected against, and stick around even 
though it isn’t useful. Take the tailbone. Evolutionary biologists think that as the 
climate got drier and grasslands popped up, our tail-bearing ancestors left the trees 
and started walking on land. The tails that had helped them 
in the trees began to disrupt their ability 
to walk on land. So individuals with mutations that reduced
the length of their tails became more successful at life on land, surviving long enough to pass their short

millions of years until, about 20 million years ago, our ancestors’ external tails disappeared 
altogether. Today, we know human embryos have tails
that dissolve as the embryo develops. But the stubby tailbone sticks around, probably because it doesn’t 
cause any harm— in fact, it serves a more minor function as the anchor point for certain 
other muscles. Up to 85% of people have a vestigial 
muscle called the “palmaris longus.” To see if you do, put your hand down on a flat surface 
and touch your pinkie to your thumb. If you see a little band pop up in the 
middle of your wrist, that’s the tendon that attaches to this 
now-defunct muscle. In this case, the fact that not everyone 
has it has helped us trace its function. Vestigial traits can persist when there’s 
no incentive to lose them— but since there’s also no incentive 
to keep them, random mutations will sometimes still
eliminate them from part of the population. Looking at our primate relatives, we can see that the palmaris longus

been part of the intestinal system our ancestors used for digesting

to make it smaller. Or maybe it has other benefits— for example, it might still be a reservoir

the appendix persists. Evolution is an imperfect process. Human beings are the result of millions of
years of trial, error, and random chance— and we’re full of evolutionary relics 
to remind us of that.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: From looking at its function in other primates, what do we think the “palmaris longus” muscle was once useful for?
Options: A. Gripping stone tools, B. Lifting heavy objects, C. Moving through the trees, D. Throwing projectile weapons
Correct Option: C

reproduce in a given environment are more likely to make it to the 
next generation. As the environment changes, traits 
that were once useful can become harmful. Those traits are often selected against, meaning they gradually disappear 
from the population. But if a trait isn’t actively harmful, 
it might not get selected against, and stick around even 
though it isn’t useful. Take the tailbone. Evolutionary biologists think that as the 
climate got drier and grasslands popped up, our tail-bearing ancestors left the trees 
and started walking on land. The tails that had helped them 
in the trees began to disrupt their ability 
to walk on land. So individuals with mutations that reduced
the length of their tails became more successful at life on land, surviving long enough to pass their short 
tails on to the next generation. The change was likely gradual over 
millions of years until, about 20 million years ago, our ancestors’ external tails disappeared 
altogether. Today, we know human embryos have tails
that dissolve as the embryo develops. But the stubby tailbone sticks around, probably because it doesn’t 
cause any harm— in fact, it serves a more minor function as the anchor point for certain 
other muscles. Up to 85% of people have a vestigial 
muscle called the “palmaris longus.” To see if you do, put your hand down on a flat surface 
and touch your pinkie to your thumb. If you see a little band pop up in the 
middle of your wrist, that’s the tendon that attaches to this 
now-defunct muscle. In this case, the fact that not everyone 
has it has helped us trace its function. Vestigial traits can persist when there’s 
no incentive to lose them— but since there’s also no incentive 
to keep them, random mutations will sometimes still
eliminate them from part of the population. Looking at our primate relatives, we can see that the palmaris longus 
is sometimes absent in those that spend more time on the land, but always present in those that spend 
more time in trees. So we think it used to help us swing 
from branch to branch, and became unnecessary when 
we moved down to land. The appendix, meanwhile, may once have 
been part of the intestinal system our ancestors used for digesting 
plant materials. As their diets changed, those parts of the
intestinal system began to shrink. Unlike other vestigial structures, though,
the appendix isn’t always harmless— it can become dangerously inflamed. For most of human history, a burst 
appendix could be a death sentence. So why did it stick around? It’s possible that it was very slowly on 
its way out, or that mutations simply hadn’t arisen 
to make it smaller. Or maybe it has other benefits— for example, it might still be a reservoir
of bacteria that helps us break down food. But the fact is, we’re not really sure why
the appendix persists. Evolution is an imperfect process. Human beings are the result of millions of
years of trial, error, and random chance— and we’re full of evolutionary relics 
to remind us of that.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Approximately how long ago did humans lose their tails?
Options: A. 10 million years ago, B. 400,000 years ago, C. 20 million years ago, D. 2 million years ago
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the vestigial structure located in the corner of the human eye? Options: A. Plica semilunaris, B. Palmaris longus, C. Tailbone, D. Appendix Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the primary reason why vestigial structures like the plica semilunaris have remained in the human body? Options: A. They provide a significant advantage for survival, B. They are actively selected for by natural selection, C. They do not cause harm and are not selected against, D. They are necessary for development Correct Option: C
Question 3: If a person has a palmaris longus muscle, what action can they perform to make the tendon visible? Options: A. Touching their thumb to their index finger, B. Touching their pinkie to their thumb, C. Flexing their wrist, D. Extending their arm Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the likely reason why the palmaris longus muscle is sometimes absent in primates that spend more time on land? Options: A. It is not necessary for swinging from branches, B. It is not necessary for walking on land, C. It is more prone to injury on land, D. It is less efficient for grasping Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the proposed original function of the appendix? Options: A. To aid in the digestion of plant materials, B. To filter waste from the bloodstream, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To produce hormones Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why might the appendix still be present in the human body despite being vestigial? Options: A. It has a significant benefit for survival, B. It has not had time to evolve out of the population, C. It may have other benefits, such as serving as a reservoir of bacteria, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: A person is diagnosed with a burst appendix. What is the most likely outcome if left untreated? Options: A. The appendix will heal on its own, B. The person will experience mild discomfort, C. The person will experience severe pain and potentially life-threatening complications, D. The person will not be affected Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the term for the process by which traits that are no longer useful are gradually eliminated from a population? Options: A. Natural selection, B. Genetic drift, C. Mutation, D. Selection against Correct Option: D
Question 9: How do evolutionary biologists think the tailbone became vestigial in humans? Options: A. As humans evolved to live in trees, the tailbone became less necessary, B. As humans evolved to walk on land, the tailbone became less necessary, C. As humans evolved to swim, the tailbone became less necessary, D. As humans evolved to fly, the tailbone became less necessary Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea that the existence of vestigial structures in humans illustrates? Options: A. Evolution is a perfect process, B. Humans are the pinnacle of evolution, C. Evolution is an imperfect process that results in remnants of past traits, D. Humans are not subject to the forces of evolution Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A few months ago we posed a challenge 
to our community. We asked everyone: given a range of 
integers from 0 to 100, guess the whole number closest to 2/3 
of the average of all numbers guessed. So if the average of all guesses is 60, 
the correct guess will be 40. What number do you think was the 
correct guess at 2/3 of the average? Let’s see if we can try and reason 
our way to the answer. This game is played under conditions known
to game theorists as common knowledge. Not only does every player have 
the same information — they also know that everyone else does, and that everyone else knows that 
everyone else does, and so on, infinitely. Now, the highest possible average would 
occur if every person guessed 100. In that case, 2/3 of the average 
would be 66.66. Since everyone can figure this out, it wouldn’t make sense to guess 
anything higher than 67. If everyone playing comes to 
this same conclusion, no one will guess higher than 67. Now 67 is the new highest 
possible average, so no reasonable guess should be 
higher than ⅔ of that, which is 44. This logic can be extended further 
and further. With each step, the highest possible 
logical answer keeps getting smaller. So it would seem sensible to guess the 
lowest number possible. And indeed, if everyone chose zero, the game would reach what’s known 
as a Nash Equilibrium. This is a state where every player has 
chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given 
everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit 
by choosing differently. But, that’s not what happens 
in the real world. People, as it turns out, either aren’t 
perfectly rational, or don’t expect each other 
to be perfectly rational. Or, perhaps, it’s some combination 
of the two. When this game is played in 
real-world settings, the average tends to be somewhere 
between 20 and 35. Danish newspaper Politiken ran the game 
with over 19,000 readers participating, resulting in an average of roughly 22, 
making the correct answer 14. For our audience, the average was 31.3. So if you guessed 21 as 2/3 of 
the average, well done. Economic game theorists have a 
way of modeling this interplay between rationality and practicality 
called k-level reasoning. K stands for the number of times a 
cycle of reasoning is repeated. A person playing at k-level 0 would 
approach our game naively, guessing a number at random without 
thinking about the other players. At k-level 1, a player would assume 
everyone else was playing at level 0, resulting in an average of 50, 
and thus guess 33. At k-level 2, they’d assume that everyone 
else was playing at level 1, leading them to guess 22. It would take 12 k-levels to reach 0. The evidence suggests that most 
people stop at 1 or 2 k-levels. And that’s useful to know, because k-level thinking comes into 
play in high-stakes situations. For example, stock traders evaluate stocks
not only based on earnings reports, but also on the value that others 
place on those numbers. And during penalty kicks in soccer, both the shooter and the goalie decide 
whether to go right or left based on what they think the other 
person is thinking. Goalies often memorize the patterns of 
their opponents ahead of time, but penalty shooters know that 
and can plan accordingly. In each case, participants must weigh 
their own understanding of the best course of action against how 
well they think other participants understand the situation. But 1 or 2 k-levels is by no means 
a hard and fast rule— simply being conscious of this tendency 
can make people adjust their expectations. For instance, what would happen 
if people played the 2/3 game after understanding the difference between
the most logical approach and the most common? Submit your own guess at what 2/3 
of the new average will be by using the form below, and we’ll find out.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you think your opponents are playing at level-3, then you want to play at level:
Options: A. 3, B. 2, C. 4, D. 0
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the challenge posed to the community in the game described in the transcript? Options: A. To guess a number closest to the average of all numbers guessed., B. To guess a number closest to 2/3 of the average of all numbers guessed., C. To guess a number closest to 1/3 of the average of all numbers guessed., D. To guess a number closest to the highest possible average. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term used to describe the state where every player has chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit by choosing differently? Options: A. Nash Equilibrium, B. Common Knowledge, C. K-Level Reasoning, D. Game Theory Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the average guess in real-world settings of the game? Options: A. Between 40 and 60, B. Between 20 and 35, C. Between 10 and 20, D. Between 60 and 80 Correct Option: B
Question 4: A person playing at k-level 0 would approach the game in what way? Options: A. By assuming everyone else is playing at level 1, B. By assuming everyone else is playing at level 2, C. By guessing a number at random without thinking about the other players, D. By analyzing the patterns of their opponents Correct Option: C
Question 5: How many k-levels would it take to reach a guess of 0 in the game? Options: A. 5, B. 10, C. 12, D. 15 Correct Option: C
Question 6: In high-stakes situations like stock trading, what do participants need to weigh against each other? Options: A. Their own understanding of the best course of action against the value of the stocks, B. Their own understanding of the best course of action against how well they think other participants understand the situation, C. The value of the stocks against the patterns of their opponents, D. The patterns of their opponents against the value of the stocks Correct Option: B
Question 7: What would happen to the average guess in the game if everyone chose zero? Options: A. The average would increase, B. The average would decrease, C. The game would reach a Nash Equilibrium, D. The game would become unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 8: How can being conscious of the tendency to stop at 1 or 2 k-levels affect people's behavior in the game? Options: A. It would make them more likely to guess randomly, B. It would make them more likely to analyze the patterns of their opponents, C. It would make them adjust their expectations, D. It would make them less likely to participate in the game Correct Option: C
Question 9: In the context of penalty kicks in soccer, what do goalies often do to gain an advantage? Options: A. They analyze the patterns of their opponents, B. They memorize the patterns of their opponents ahead of time, C. They try to distract the shooter, D. They rely on luck Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what was the average guess of the audience in the game? Options: A. 22, B. 31.3, C. 40, D. 60 Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the concept of k-level reasoning, which is the main topic of the ground truth MCQ.

The most similar generated MCQ is Question 4, which asks about the behavior of a person playing at k-level 0. Although this question does not directly ask about playing at a level higher than the opponents, it is related to the concept of k-level reasoning and how players think about their opponents' strategies.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is more similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, I would suggest Question 5, which asks about the number of k-levels it would take to reach a guess of 0 in the game. This question is more related to the concept of k-level reasoning and the idea of thinking about the opponents' strategies, but it is still not a direct match to the ground truth MCQ.

Since none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ, I would recommend creating a new generated MCQ that directly asks about playing at a level higher than the opponents, similar to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A few months ago we posed a challenge 
to our community. We asked everyone: given a range of 
integers from 0 to 100, guess the whole number closest to 2/3 
of the average of all numbers guessed. So if the average of all guesses is 60, 
the correct guess will be 40. What number do you think was the 
correct guess at 2/3 of the average? Let’s see if we can try and reason 
our way to the answer. This game is played under conditions known
to game theorists as common knowledge. Not only does every player have 
the same information — they also know that everyone else does, and that everyone else knows that 
everyone else does, and so on, infinitely. Now, the highest possible average would 
occur if every person guessed 100. In that case, 2/3 of the average 
would be 66.66. Since everyone can figure this out, it wouldn’t make sense to guess 
anything higher than 67. If everyone playing comes to 
this same conclusion, no one will guess higher than 67. Now 67 is the new highest 
possible average, so no reasonable guess should be 
higher than ⅔ of that, which is 44. This logic can be extended further 
and further. With each step, the highest possible 
logical answer keeps getting smaller. So it would seem sensible to guess the 
lowest number possible. And indeed, if everyone chose zero, the game would reach what’s known 
as a Nash Equilibrium. This is a state where every player has 
chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given 
everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit 
by choosing differently. But, that’s not what happens 
in the real world. People, as it turns out, either aren’t 
perfectly rational, or don’t expect each other 
to be perfectly rational. Or, perhaps, it’s some combination 
of the two. When this game is played in 
real-world settings, the average tends to be somewhere 
between 20 and 35. Danish newspaper Politiken ran the game 
with over 19,000 readers participating, resulting in an average of roughly 22, 
making the correct answer 14. For our audience, the average was 31.3. So if you guessed 21 as 2/3 of 
the average, well done. Economic game theorists have a 
way of modeling this interplay between rationality and practicality 
called k-level reasoning. K stands for the number of times a 
cycle of reasoning is repeated. A person playing at k-level 0 would 
approach our game naively, guessing a number at random without 
thinking about the other players. At k-level 1, a player would assume 
everyone else was playing at level 0, resulting in an average of 50, 
and thus guess 33. At k-level 2, they’d assume that everyone 
else was playing at level 1, leading them to guess 22. It would take 12 k-levels to reach 0. The evidence suggests that most 
people stop at 1 or 2 k-levels. And that’s useful to know, because k-level thinking comes into 
play in high-stakes situations. For example, stock traders evaluate stocks
not only based on earnings reports, but also on the value that others 
place on those numbers. And during penalty kicks in soccer, both the shooter and the goalie decide 
whether to go right or left based on what they think the other 
person is thinking. Goalies often memorize the patterns of 
their opponents ahead of time, but penalty shooters know that 
and can plan accordingly. In each case, participants must weigh 
their own understanding of the best course of action against how 
well they think other participants understand the situation. But 1 or 2 k-levels is by no means 
a hard and fast rule— simply being conscious of this tendency 
can make people adjust their expectations. For instance, what would happen 
if people played the 2/3 game after understanding the difference between
the most logical approach and the most common? Submit your own guess at what 2/3 
of the new average will be by using the form below, and we’ll find out.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Your phone dies but you were supposed to meet up with a good friend at one of two locations across the city by 7pm. You were supposed to mutually confirm with them a location. Under what scenarios do you need to apply k-level reasoning?
Options: A. Your friend is nice and knows your favorite spot., B. Your friend is mean and you know her favorite spot., C. Your friend told you where she would like last week, but she is forgetful., D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the challenge posed to the community in the game described in the transcript? Options: A. To guess a number closest to the average of all numbers guessed., B. To guess a number closest to 2/3 of the average of all numbers guessed., C. To guess a number closest to 1/3 of the average of all numbers guessed., D. To guess a number closest to the highest possible average. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term used to describe the state where every player has chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit by choosing differently? Options: A. Nash Equilibrium, B. Common Knowledge, C. K-Level Reasoning, D. Game Theory Correct Option: A
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the average guess in real-world settings of the game? Options: A. Between 40 and 60, B. Between 20 and 35, C. Between 10 and 20, D. Between 60 and 80 Correct Option: B
Question 4: A person playing at k-level 0 would approach the game in what way? Options: A. By assuming everyone else is playing at level 1, B. By assuming everyone else is playing at level 2, C. By guessing a number at random without thinking about the other players, D. By analyzing the patterns of their opponents Correct Option: C
Question 5: How many k-levels would it take to reach a guess of 0 in the game? Options: A. 5, B. 10, C. 12, D. 15 Correct Option: C
Question 6: In high-stakes situations like stock trading, what do participants need to weigh against each other? Options: A. Their own understanding of the best course of action against the value of the stocks, B. Their own understanding of the best course of action against how well they think other participants understand the situation, C. The value of the stocks against the patterns of their opponents, D. The patterns of their opponents against the value of the stocks Correct Option: B
Question 7: What would happen to the average guess in the game if everyone chose zero? Options: A. The average would increase, B. The average would decrease, C. The game would reach a Nash Equilibrium, D. The game would become unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 8: How can being conscious of the tendency to stop at 1 or 2 k-levels affect people's behavior in the game? Options: A. It would make them more likely to guess randomly, B. It would make them more likely to analyze the patterns of their opponents, C. It would make them adjust their expectations, D. It would make them less likely to participate in the game Correct Option: C
Question 9: In the context of penalty kicks in soccer, what do goalies often do to gain an advantage? Options: A. They analyze the patterns of their opponents, B. They memorize the patterns of their opponents ahead of time, C. They try to distract the shooter, D. They rely on luck Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what was the average guess of the audience in the game? Options: A. 22, B. 31.3, C. 40, D. 60 Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match in terms of content, but rather in terms of the concept of k-level reasoning being applied in a real-world scenario.

The ground truth MCQ asks about applying k-level reasoning in a situation where you need to meet up with a friend at one of two locations, and you need to consider what your friend might be thinking.

The most similar generated MCQ is Question 6, which asks about what participants need to weigh against each other in high-stakes situations like stock trading. While the context is different, the concept of considering what others might be thinking is similar.

However, another generated MCQ that comes close is Question 9, which asks about what goalies often do to gain an advantage in penalty kicks in soccer. This question also involves considering what the other person (the shooter) might be thinking.

But if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 6 is the most similar generated MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A few months ago we posed a challenge 
to our community. We asked everyone: given a range of 
integers from 0 to 100, guess the whole number closest to 2/3 
of the average of all numbers guessed. So if the average of all guesses is 60, 
the correct guess will be 40. What number do you think was the 
correct guess at 2/3 of the average? Let’s see if we can try and reason 
our way to the answer. This game is played under conditions known
to game theorists as common knowledge. Not only does every player have 
the same information — they also know that everyone else does, and that everyone else knows that 
everyone else does, and so on, infinitely. Now, the highest possible average would 
occur if every person guessed 100. In that case, 2/3 of the average 
would be 66.66. Since everyone can figure this out, it wouldn’t make sense to guess 
anything higher than 67. If everyone playing comes to 
this same conclusion, no one will guess higher than 67. Now 67 is the new highest 
possible average, so no reasonable guess should be 
higher than ⅔ of that, which is 44. This logic can be extended further 
and further. With each step, the highest possible 
logical answer keeps getting smaller. So it would seem sensible to guess the 
lowest number possible. And indeed, if everyone chose zero, the game would reach what’s known 
as a Nash Equilibrium. This is a state where every player has 
chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given 
everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit 
by choosing differently. But, that’s not what happens 
in the real world. People, as it turns out, either aren’t 
perfectly rational, or don’t expect each other 
to be perfectly rational. Or, perhaps, it’s some combination 
of the two. When this game is played in 
real-world settings, the average tends to be somewhere 
between 20 and 35. Danish newspaper Politiken ran the game 
with over 19,000 readers participating, resulting in an average of roughly 22, 
making the correct answer 14. For our audience, the average was 31.3. So if you guessed 21 as 2/3 of 
the average, well done. Economic game theorists have a 
way of modeling this interplay between rationality and practicality 
called k-level reasoning. K stands for the number of times a 
cycle of reasoning is repeated. A person playing at k-level 0 would 
approach our game naively, guessing a number at random without 
thinking about the other players. At k-level 1, a player would assume 
everyone else was playing at level 0, resulting in an average of 50, 
and thus guess 33. At k-level 2, they’d assume that everyone 
else was playing at level 1, leading them to guess 22. It would take 12 k-levels to reach 0. The evidence suggests that most 
people stop at 1 or 2 k-levels. And that’s useful to know, because k-level thinking comes into 
play in high-stakes situations. For example, stock traders evaluate stocks
not only based on earnings reports, but also on the value that others 
place on those numbers. And during penalty kicks in soccer, both the shooter and the goalie decide 
whether to go right or left based on what they think the other 
person is thinking. Goalies often memorize the patterns of 
their opponents ahead of time, but penalty shooters know that 
and can plan accordingly. In each case, participants must weigh 
their own understanding of the best course of action against how 
well they think other participants understand the situation. But 1 or 2 k-levels is by no means 
a hard and fast rule— simply being conscious of this tendency 
can make people adjust their expectations. For instance, what would happen 
if people played the 2/3 game after understanding the difference between
the most logical approach and the most common? Submit your own guess at what 2/3 
of the new average will be by using the form below, and we’ll find out.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A Nash equilibrium is when:
Options: A. You can’t do any better than your current strategy., B. You and your opponent can mutually never do better than the current strategies., C. Like a cartel, you coordinate even though cheating on the arrangement is lucrative., D. All of the above.
Correct Option: B

To guess a number closest to 2/3 of the average of all numbers guessed., C. To guess a number closest to 1/3 of the average of all numbers guessed., D. To guess a number closest to the highest possible average. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the term used to describe the state where every player has chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit by choosing differently? Options: A. Nash Equilibrium, B. Common Knowledge, C. K-Level Reasoning, D. Game Theory Correct Option: A

Question 4: A person playing at k-level 0 would approach the game in what way? Options: A. By assuming everyone else is playing at level 1, B. By assuming everyone else is playing at level 2, C. By guessing a number at random without thinking about the other players, D. By analyzing the patterns of their opponents Correct Option: C
Question 5: How many k-levels would it take to reach a guess of 0 in the game? Options: A. 5, B. 10, C. 12, D. 15 Correct Option: C
Question 6: In high-stakes situations like stock trading, what do participants need to weigh against each other? Options: A. Their own understanding of the best course of action against the value of the stocks, B. Their own understanding of the best course of action against how well they think other participants understand the situation, C. The value of the stocks against the patterns of their opponents, D. The patterns of their opponents against the value of the stocks Correct Option: B
Question 7: What would happen to the average guess in the game if everyone chose zero? Options: A. The average would increase, B. The average would decrease, C. The game would reach a Nash Equilibrium, D. The game would become unpredictable Correct Option: C
Question 8: How can being conscious of the tendency to stop at 1 or 2 k-levels affect people's behavior in the game? Options: A. It would make them more likely to guess randomly, B. It would make them more likely to analyze the patterns of their opponents, C. It would make them adjust their expectations, D. It would make them less likely to participate in the game Correct Option: C

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off 
completely from the celestial realm, and the brothers wandered aimlessly, even more lost than they had been before. One day, three of the brothers 
stumbled upon a house. In the house lived an elder named 
Bayamanacao, and he invited them in. When Deminan caught up slightly later, 
he followed them into the house. Bayamanacao told the brothers 
he was their grandfather and gave them a gift of special 
cassava bread. He revealed their family lineage to them: their mother had been the Earth Mother 
Goddess Itibi Cahubaba and had died when they were born. The brothers were grateful for his 
hospitality and insight into their past. But then Bayamanacao turned on Deminan, blowing tobacco spittle from his nose 
onto Deminan’s back. The spot where the spittle landed 
immediately began to swell and sting. Soon Deminan was delirious and his back was so swollen his 
brothers feared he would die. Not knowing what else to do, 
they cut open the welt. A turtle emerged from the 
wound and swam away, alternating easily between sea 
and land as she went. When Deminan recovered from his delirium, he finally understood what the 
curse of his disease meant: he was a caracaracol, 
able to communicate with the gods. He was the link between the celestial 
realm and the earthly realm. Deminan was the first in a long 
lineage of caracaracols. The world of seas he and his brothers 
had created when they dropped the gourd became the world of humans, where the caracaracols who followed 
Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Deminán had how many brothers?
Options: A. one, B. two, C. three, D. four
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the world of the gods made of, according to the myth? Options: A. Seas, islands, and caves, B. Fields, plains, and gardens, C. Deserts, mountains, and forests, D. Rivers, lakes, and waterfalls Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why did Deminan wonder about his appearance? Options: A. He was taller than his brothers, B. He had a different eye color, C. His skin was covered in painful scabs, D. He had a different hair color Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the result of the brothers dropping the giant gourd in Yaya's house? Options: A. A great storm swept the land, B. A deluge was released, creating a new world, C. The brothers were punished by Yaya, D. The gourd was magically restored Correct Option: B
Question 4: What did Bayamanacao reveal to the brothers about their family lineage? Options: A. They were the sons of Yaya, B. They were the sons of the Earth Mother Goddess Itibi Cahubaba, C. They were the sons of a mortal king, D. They were the sons of a sea god Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the turtle emerging from Deminan's wound? Options: A. It was a sign of Deminan's death, B. It was a sign of Deminan's healing, C. It was a sign of Deminan's connection to the gods, D. It was a sign of Deminan's connection to the sea Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was Deminan's role in the myth? Options: A. He was the supreme spirit, B. He was the Earth Mother Goddess, C. He was a caracaracol, a link between the celestial and earthly realms, D. He was a mortal king Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the price of the caracaracols' unique power? Options: A. They had to live in the celestial realm, B. They had to live in the earthly realm, C. They had to suffer from the illness that marked Deminan as special, D. They had to give up their connection to the gods Correct Option: C
Question 8: How did the world of seas created by the brothers differ from the celestial realm? Options: A. It was more beautiful, B. It was more peaceful, C. It was covered in seas, which didn't exist in the celestial realm, D. It was more fertile Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be inferred about the significance of the caracaracols in Taino culture? Options: A. They were seen as cursed beings, B. They were seen as blessed beings, C. They were seen as a necessary link between the celestial and earthly realms, D. They were seen as insignificant Correct Option: C
Question 10: What message do you think the myth is trying to convey about the relationship between humans and the gods? Options: A. That humans should fear the gods, B. That humans should worship the gods, C. That humans need a mediator to communicate with the gods, D. That humans are equal to the gods Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the number of brothers Deminán had. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 2 does mention Deminán's brothers in the context of his appearance.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest Question 3, which mentions "the brothers" in the context of an event. But it does not directly ask about the number of brothers.

Since there is no direct match, I will not provide an index of a matching generated MCQ. Instead, I suggest generating new MCQs that directly address the ground truth MCQs.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off 
completely from the celestial realm, and the brothers wandered aimlessly, even more lost than they had been before. One day, three of the brothers 
stumbled upon a house. In the house lived an elder named 
Bayamanacao, and he invited them in. When Deminan caught up slightly later, 
he followed them into the house. Bayamanacao told the brothers 
he was their grandfather and gave them a gift of special 
cassava bread. He revealed their family lineage to them: their mother had been the Earth Mother 
Goddess Itibi Cahubaba and had died when they were born. The brothers were grateful for his 
hospitality and insight into their past. But then Bayamanacao turned on Deminan, blowing tobacco spittle from his nose 
onto Deminan’s back. The spot where the spittle landed 
immediately began to swell and sting. Soon Deminan was delirious and his back was so swollen his 
brothers feared he would die. Not knowing what else to do, 
they cut open the welt. A turtle emerged from the 
wound and swam away, alternating easily between sea 
and land as she went. When Deminan recovered from his delirium, he finally understood what the 
curse of his disease meant: he was a caracaracol, 
able to communicate with the gods. He was the link between the celestial 
realm and the earthly realm. Deminan was the first in a long 
lineage of caracaracols. The world of seas he and his brothers 
had created when they dropped the gourd became the world of humans, where the caracaracols who followed 
Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When the welt on Deminán’s back was cut open, what came out?
Options: A. a frog, B. a snake, C. a bird, D. a turtle
Correct Option: D

Question 2: Why did Deminan wonder about his appearance? Options: A. He was taller than his brothers, B. He had a different eye color, C. His skin was covered in painful scabs, D. He had a different hair color Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off 
completely from the celestial realm, and the brothers wandered aimlessly, even more lost than they had been before. One day, three of the brothers 
stumbled upon a house. In the house lived an elder named 
Bayamanacao, and he invited them in. When Deminan caught up slightly later, 
he followed them into the house. Bayamanacao told the brothers 
he was their grandfather and gave them a gift of special 
cassava bread. He revealed their family lineage to them: their mother had been the Earth Mother 
Goddess Itibi Cahubaba and had died when they were born. The brothers were grateful for his 
hospitality and insight into their past. But then Bayamanacao turned on Deminan, blowing tobacco spittle from his nose 
onto Deminan’s back. The spot where the spittle landed 
immediately began to swell and sting. Soon Deminan was delirious and his back was so swollen his 
brothers feared he would die. Not knowing what else to do, 
they cut open the welt. A turtle emerged from the 
wound and swam away, alternating easily between sea 
and land as she went. When Deminan recovered from his delirium, he finally understood what the 
curse of his disease meant: he was a caracaracol, 
able to communicate with the gods. He was the link between the celestial 
realm and the earthly realm. Deminan was the first in a long 
lineage of caracaracols. The world of seas he and his brothers 
had created when they dropped the gourd became the world of humans, where the caracaracols who followed 
Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When the gourd was broken, what was released?
Options: A. a strong wind, B. the sea, C. cassava seeds, D. an evil monster
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the world of the gods made of, according to the myth? Options: A. Seas, islands, and caves, B. Fields, plains, and gardens, C. Deserts, mountains, and forests, D. Rivers, lakes, and waterfalls Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why did Deminan wonder about his appearance? Options: A. He was taller than his brothers, B. He had a different eye color, C. His skin was covered in painful scabs, D. He had a different hair color Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the result of the brothers dropping the giant gourd in Yaya's house? Options: A. A great storm swept the land, B. A deluge was released, creating a new world, C. The brothers were punished by Yaya, D. The gourd was magically restored Correct Option: B
Question 4: What did Bayamanacao reveal to the brothers about their family lineage? Options: A. They were the sons of Yaya, B. They were the sons of the Earth Mother Goddess Itibi Cahubaba, C. They were the sons of a mortal king, D. They were the sons of a sea god Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the significance of the turtle emerging from Deminan's wound? Options: A. It was a sign of Deminan's death, B. It was a sign of Deminan's healing, C. It was a sign of Deminan's connection to the gods, D. It was a sign of Deminan's connection to the sea Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was Deminan's role in the myth? Options: A. He was the supreme spirit, B. He was the Earth Mother Goddess, C. He was a caracaracol, a link between the celestial and earthly realms, D. He was a mortal king Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the price of the caracaracols' unique power? Options: A. They had to live in the celestial realm, B. They had to live in the earthly realm, C. They had to suffer from the illness that marked Deminan as special, D. They had to give up their connection to the gods Correct Option: C
Question 8: How did the world of seas created by the brothers differ from the celestial realm? Options: A. It was more beautiful, B. It was more peaceful, C. It was covered in seas, which didn't exist in the celestial realm, D. It was more fertile Correct Option: C
Question 9: What can be inferred about the significance of the caracaracols in Taino culture? Options: A. They were seen as cursed beings, B. They were seen as blessed beings, C. They were seen as a necessary link between the celestial and earthly realms, D. They were seen as insignificant Correct Option: C
Question 10: What message do you think the myth is trying to convey about the relationship between humans and the gods? Options: A. That humans should fear the gods, B. That humans should worship the gods, C. That humans need a mediator to communicate with the gods, D. That humans are equal to the gods Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (the consequence of the gourd being broken) and content (the release of a deluge creating a new world). The correct option in Question 3 (B. A deluge was released, creating a new world) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (B. the sea), as the deluge in the myth is described as forming a new world covered in seas.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off 
completely from the celestial realm, and the brothers wandered aimlessly, even more lost than they had been before. One day, three of the brothers 
stumbled upon a house. In the house lived an elder named 
Bayamanacao, and he invited them in. When Deminan caught up slightly later, 
he followed them into the house. Bayamanacao told the brothers 
he was their grandfather and gave them a gift of special 
cassava bread. He revealed their family lineage to them: their mother had been the Earth Mother 
Goddess Itibi Cahubaba and had died when they were born. The brothers were grateful for his 
hospitality and insight into their past. But then Bayamanacao turned on Deminan, blowing tobacco spittle from his nose 
onto Deminan’s back. The spot where the spittle landed 
immediately began to swell and sting. Soon Deminan was delirious and his back was so swollen his 
brothers feared he would die. Not knowing what else to do, 
they cut open the welt. A turtle emerged from the 
wound and swam away, alternating easily between sea 
and land as she went. When Deminan recovered from his delirium, he finally understood what the 
curse of his disease meant: he was a caracaracol, 
able to communicate with the gods. He was the link between the celestial 
realm and the earthly realm. Deminan was the first in a long 
lineage of caracaracols. The world of seas he and his brothers 
had created when they dropped the gourd became the world of humans, where the caracaracols who followed 
Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Deminán was different from his brothers because he had
Options: A. scabby skin, B. a broken leg, C. blonde hair, D. a scar on his forehead
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off

Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The year was 1776. In Bavaria, new ideals of rationalism, 
religious freedom, and universal human rights competed with the Catholic church’s 
heavy influence over public affairs. Across the Atlantic, a new nation staked its claim for 
independence on the basis of these ideas. But back in Bavaria, law professor Adam Weishaupt’s 
attempts to teach secular philosophy continued to be frustrated. Weishaupt decided to spread his ideas 
through a secret society that would shine a light on the 
shortcomings of the Church’s ideology. He called his secret society 
the Illuminati. Weishaupt modelled aspects of his secret 
society off a group called the Freemasons. Originally an elite stoneworkers’ 
guild in the late Middle Ages, the Freemasons had gone from passing 
down the craft of masonry to more generally promoting ideals of 
knowledge and reason. Over time, they had grown into a 
semi-secret, exclusive order that included many wealthy and 
influential individuals, with elaborate, secret initiation rituals. Weishaupt created his parallel 
society while also joining the Freemasons and recruiting from their ranks. He adopted the code name 
Spartacus for himself, after the famed leader of the 
Roman slave revolt. Early members became the Illuminati’s 
ruling council, or Areopagus. One of these members, Baron Adolph 
Knigge, was also a freemason, and became an influential recruiter. With Knigge’s help, the Illuminati 
expanded their numbers, gained influence within 
several Masonic chapters, and incorporated Masonic rituals. By 1784, there were over 600 members, including influential scholars 
and politicians. As the Illuminati gained members, the American Revolution also 
gained momentum. Thomas Jefferson would later cite 
Weishaupt as an inspiration. European monarchs and clergy were fearful 
of similar revolts on their home soil. Meanwhile, the existence of the Illuminati
had become an open secret. Both the Illuminati and the Freemasons 
drew exclusively from society’s wealthy elite, which meant they were constantly 
rubbing shoulders with members of the religious and 
political establishment. Many in the government and church 
believed that both groups were determined to undermine the 
people’s religious faith. But these groups didn’t necessarily 
oppose religion— they just believed it should be kept 
separate from governance. Still, the suspicious Bavarian government 
started keeping records of alleged members of the Illuminati. Just as Illuminati members begun to secure
important positions in local governments and universities, a 1784 decree by Duke Karl Theodor 
of Bavaria banned all secret societies. While a public ban on something ostensibly
secret might seem difficult to enforce, in this case it worked. Only nine years after its founding, the group dissolved, 
their records were seized, and Weishaupt forced into exile. The Illuminati would become more 
notorious in their afterlife than they had ever been in 
their brief existence. A decade later, in the aftermath 
of the French Revolution, conservative authors claimed the 
Illuminati had survived their banishment and orchestrated the overthrow 
of the monarchy. In the United States, preacher Jedidiah Morse promoted 
similar ideas of an Illuminati conspiracy against the government. But though the idea of a secret group 
orchestrating political upheaval is still alive and well today, there is no
evidence that the Illuminati survived, reformed, or went underground. Their brief tenure is well-documented 
in Bavarian government records, the still-active Freemasons’s records, and particularly the overlap between 
these two sources, without a whisper since. In the spirit of rationalism the 
Illuminati embraced, one must conclude they no longer exist. But the ideas that spurred Weishaupt 
to found the illuminati still spread, becoming the basis for many Western 
governments today. These ideas didn’t start or end 
with the Illuminati— instead, it was one community that 
represented a wave of change that was already underway 
when it was founded and continued long after it ended.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Illuminati's ruling council were known as the:
Options: A. Parliamentarians, B. Areopagus, C. Spartacus, D. The chamber
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year did Adam Weishaupt found the Illuminati? Options: A. 1766, B. 1776, C. 1784, D. 1786 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason Adam Weishaupt created the Illuminati? Options: A. To promote the Catholic Church's influence over public affairs, B. To spread secular philosophy and shine a light on the shortcomings of the Church's ideology, C. To create a secret society for wealthy elites, D. To overthrow the monarchy Correct Option: B
Question 3: Which group did Adam Weishaupt model aspects of the Illuminati after? Options: A. The Freemasons, B. The Catholic Church, C. The Roman Empire, D. The American Revolutionaries Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the name of the Illuminati's ruling council? Options: A. Areopagus, B. Freemasons, C. Illuminati Council, D. The Spartacus Group Correct Option: A
Question 5: How many members did the Illuminati have by 1784? Options: A. Over 100, B. Over 600, C. Over 1,000, D. Over 10,000 Correct Option: B
Question 6: What event in 1784 led to the dissolution of the Illuminati? Options: A. The American Revolution, B. The French Revolution, C. A decree by Duke Karl Theodor of Bavaria banning all secret societies, D. The death of Adam Weishaupt Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the primary goal of the Illuminati and the Freemasons, according to the transcript? Options: A. To undermine the people's religious faith, B. To promote the Catholic Church's influence over public affairs, C. To keep religion separate from governance, D. To overthrow the monarchy Correct Option: C
Question 8: What conspiracy theory emerged in the aftermath of the French Revolution? Options: A. The Illuminati had survived their banishment and orchestrated the overthrow of the monarchy, B. The Freemasons had planned the American Revolution, C. The Catholic Church had secretly funded the Illuminati, D. The Illuminati had infiltrated the government Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the conclusion based on the available evidence regarding the Illuminati's existence after their banishment? Options: A. They survived and went underground, B. They reformed and continued to influence politics, C. They no longer exist, D. There is not enough evidence to conclude anything Correct Option: C
Question 10: What legacy did the Illuminati leave behind, according to the transcript? Options: A. A secret society that still exists today, B. A wave of change that was already underway when it was founded and continued long after it ended, C. A conspiracy theory that still influences politics today, D. A failed attempt to undermine the Catholic Church Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 4: What was the name of the Illuminati's ruling council? Options: A. Areopagus, B. Freemasons, C. Illuminati Council, D. The Spartacus Group Correct Option: A**

This question has the same intent and content as the ground truth MCQ, asking about the name of the Illuminati's ruling council. The correct option, "Areopagus", is also the same in both questions.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **4**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The year was 1776. In Bavaria, new ideals of rationalism,

represented a wave of change that was already underway 
when it was founded and continued long after it ended.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was the Bavarian law professor who founded the Illuminati?
Options: A. Adam Weishaupt, B. Baron Adolph Knigge, C. Thomas Jefferson, D. Karl Theodor
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
